text.p: Transport company Vitransauto said on Monday that it sees a tough 1997 ahead but hopes to keep its position on the market.
The company's 1997 budget forecasts 29,000 lats of profit on some 3.9 million lats of turnover against a 1996 profit of 22,000 lats on 3.7 million lats of turnover.
"Shareholders on Saturday approved slightly higher profit and turnover firgures for 1997 but it will be a tough year," Uldis Berzinsh, Vitransauto manager, told Reuters.
"We have not received any investment and trucks are getting older while technical requirements get tougher both in the EU and Russia," Berzinsh said.
Vitransauto in 1996 had 30 percent of its transport business with Russia and 70 percent with west European countries.
"We do not plan any major changes in this repect and hope to keep our current volumes," Berzinsh said.
He also said that the controlling stake held by the Visbija trading company was still under debate after the company went bankrupt.
"Visbija, which held a 60 percent stake, announced about its liquidation last October," he said.
"It is now a matter for the lawyers to arrange for an auction of its stake," Berzinsh said.
Vitransauto, apart from Naruta confectionery, is among the few privatised companies whose controling stake owners become insolvent before the sell-off programme was completed.
